Setting up your own XSLT applications

s2.title: Downloading what you need
s2.p: For &xslt4c-current;, we are distributing a Windows32 Visual C++ build, a Red Hat Linux GNU build, and an AIX xlC_r build. Please contact us at if you would like to help provide builds for other platforms.

Each distribution contains all you need to run the Xalan command-line utility for performing transformations. To build your own applications, you also need a compatible &xml4c; binary distribution. If you want to take advantage of the support for number formatting, sorting, and encoding the ICU provides, you should also download and install the ; see Using the ICU,

s3.title: What you need to build applications
s3.p: To build your own applications with Xalan and Xerces, you also need need the Xalan-C++ and Xerces-C++ header (.hpp) files and (for Windows) the &xslt4c; and &xml4c; libraries (.lib files).
The Xalan-C++ header files are in the src directory tree in both distributions.
In the Windows32 distribution (built with Microsoft® Visual C++® 6.0), the dlls and libraries are in the Build - Win32 -V6 - Release subdirectory.
In the Linux distribution (built on Red Hat Linux 6.1 with a make file and the CNU C++ compiler), the shared object library is in the lib subdirectory.
In the AIX distribution (built with the make file and xlC_r), the load library is in the lib subdirectory.

To get the Xerces-C++ header and (for Windows) .lib files, download and expand the &xml4c; binary distribution for your platform from the . For information about which &xml4c; distribution has been tested with this &xslt4c; release, see Version of &xml4c; to use.
For information about rebuilding &xslt4c;, see the Build notes.

s2.title: Setting up the path
s2.p: For the Xalan-C++ Windows32 distribution, place xml-xalan\c\Build\Win32\VC6\Release on the path.
For the Xalan-C++ Linux distribution, place xml-xalan/c/bin and xml-xalan/c/lib on the shared library path (LD_LIBRARY_PATH for Red Hat Linux 6.1), or copy &xslt4c-linuxlib; to /usr/lib.
For the Xalan-C++ AIX distribution, place xml-xalan/c/bin and xml-xalan/c/lib on the load library path (LIB for xlC_r), or copy &xslt4c-aixlib; to /usr/lib.
If you do your own Xalan, ICU, and Xerces builds, be sure to include the directories that contain the libraries and the TextXSLT executable on your path.

If you want the output to be displayed on the screen, simply omit the -out flag and outputfile.

You can use this utility to try out XSL stylesheets you have written, to make sure they do what you expect with the XML source files they are designed to transform. The utility provides useful messages if the source file or stylesheet is not well formed. If you include a DOCTYPE statement in your XML source files and include the -validate flag on the command line, the utility will also let you know whether the XML document is valid (conforms to that DOCTYPE). For more information, see Command-Line Utility.

s2.title: Setting up your own XSLT applications
s2.p: You can start by using your own XML source files and XSL stylesheets with the sample applications, which illustrate a number of usage patterns. For more information on setting up applications, see Basic Usage Patterns.
